A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review. A total of 399 adult guinea pigs, weanlings, and
offspring were counted during this inspection. There were no records of the number of guinea pigs held or died since June
7, 2024. Failure to maintain records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying losses by
decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for
animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, or disposed of including births and deaths. Correct by
August 31, 2024

Space. Insufficient space was being provided to 6 enclosures housing weanling guinea pigs. The weanling enclosures
each measure 24 inches by 36 inches or 864 square inches of floor space. These enclosures were housing a minimum of
20 weanlings each. Weanling guinea pigs weighing up to 350 grams require at least 60 inches of floor space per animal.
Can not house more than 14 weanlings in this size enclosure.
Insufficient or inadequate space can cause stress and aggression in animals which can result in bites, wounds, ear
chewing and other injuries and health problems. Licensee must ensure that the guinea pigs are provided with at least the
minimum amount of floor space per animal to prevent overcrowding, stress, and aggression. Correct by August 31, 2024.

There were accumulations of excreta, and dirty bedding covering the floors in at least 10 guinea pig enclosures. The
primary enclosures are not being cleaned and sanitized often enough to remove excreta and dirty bedding.. Ineffective
cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health problems. Correct by ensuring that all
enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta and debris, and that enclosures are sanitized at least once
every 2 weeks. Correct by August 27, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review. A total of 399 adult guinea pigs, weanlings, and 
offspring were counted during this inspection. There were no records of the number of guinea pigs held or died since June 
7, 2024. Failure to maintain records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying losses by 
decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for 
animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, or disposed of including births and deaths. Correct by 
August 31, 2024 
3.28(c)(1)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Space. Insufficient space was being provided to 6 enclosures housing weanling guinea pigs. The weanling enclosures 
each measure 24 inches by 36 inches or 864 square inches of floor space. These enclosures were housing a minimum of 
20 weanlings each. Weanling guinea pigs weighing up to 350 grams require at least 60 inches of floor space per animal. 
Can not house more than 14 weanlings in this size enclosure.  
 
Insufficient or inadequate space can cause stress and aggression in animals which can result in bites, wounds, ear 
chewing and other injuries and health problems. Licensee must ensure that the guinea pigs are provided with at least the 
minimum amount of floor space per animal to prevent overcrowding, stress, and aggression. Correct by August 31, 2024. 
3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were accumulations of excreta, and dirty bedding covering the floors in at least 10 guinea pig enclosures. The 
primary enclosures are not being cleaned and sanitized often enough to remove excreta and dirty bedding.. Ineffective 
cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health problems. Correct by ensuring that all 
enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta and debris, and that enclosures are sanitized at least once 
every 2 weeks. Correct by August 27, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
